step.name: What to predict?
step.text: To learn about building predictive models, let's go back to the Titanic data from earlier. This data is somewhat simpler and does not need a lot of preparation, but we still need to specify which column we want to predict!

step.name: Add product details to transactions.

tasks.task: Drag the Titanic data into the process.

Now, hover the mouse over the output port of the Retrieve operator and wait for a small window to pop up and display some meta data about the Titanic dataset. Some of the information you know from the Statistics tab.
Note the two columns Role and Type in the table at the bottom.

step.info: Each attribute has a type which defines the possible values for the column (for example, if values can be nominal or numerical).

The role of an attribute describes how the column is used by machine learning operators. Attributes without any role (also called "regular" attributes) are used as input for training while id attributes are usually ignored by modeling algorithms because they are only used as unique identifiers of observations of data.

step.name: Define attribute types and roles.

tasks.task: Add a Discretize by Binning operator and connect it. In its Parameters:
Set the attribute filter type to single (i.e. you only work on one of the attributes).

step.info: "Binning" is a common technique to transform the type from numerical to polynominal (a nominal with more than 2 values). Here, we create three "bins" covering the complete range of values. The operator then replaces the original numerical value with the name of the bin the value belongs to.

step.name: Define which column to predict.
step.info: In RapidMiner, we call the column which should be predicted label. It is sometimes also known as target or class.

tasks.task: Add the Set Role operator and connect it.
In Parameters, for attribute name Survived, change target role to label.
16/media_play.pngRun the process and inspect the results.

step.info: Look at the Statistics tab in the Results view. Note that the role of Survived has changed to label. The attribute Age also has a new type now: the numerical values for Age have been replaced by new names.

step.name: Congratulations!
step.text: Great work! Setting an attribute role is useful for many things (e.g. for identifying ID-like attributes or example weights), but the most frequent use is to define the label, i.e. which attribute should be predicted based on the other attributes.
